00019 /**
00020 
00021 @page srio OCTEON II Serial RapidIO
00022 
00023 @section srio_intro 1. Introduction
00024 
00025 The OCTEON II series of processors introduced support for Serial
00026 RapidIO (SRIO) to the OCTEON family.  This document describes the
00027 Cavium Inc. API for programming SRIO under the simple executive
00028 environment, the Linux kernel, and Linux userspace.  For the Linux
00029 APIs, Cavium built on top of the existing RapidIO subsystem, but was
00030 forced to modify the kernel's API to workaround limitations (kernel
00031 version 2.6.27.7).  The Cavium specific changes are detailed under the
00032 sections describing the affected SRIO operations.
00033 
00034     - @ref srio_intro
00035     - @ref srio_maintenance
00036     - @ref srio_memory
00037     - @ref srio_doorbell
00038     - @ref srio_port_writes
00039     - @ref srio_message
00040     - @ref srio_enumeration
00041     - @ref srio_types
00042 
00043 @section srio_maintenance 2. Maintenance Operations (RapidIO format type 8)
00044 
00045 RapidIO uses "Maintenance" operations to configure the system.  As
00046 defined the the RapidIO specification, these transactions must use
00047 multiples of 4 bytes and do not having guaranteed delivery.
00048 
00049 @subsection srio_maintenance_kernel 2.1. Linux kernel
00050 
00051 The Linux kernel exposes maintenance operations through the following
00052 functions:
00053 
00054     - rio_mport_read_config_32()
00055     - rio_mport_write_config_32()
00056     - rio_local_read_config_32()
00057     - rio_local_write_config_32()
00058     - rio_read_config_32()
00059     - rio_write_config_32()
00060 
00061 @note The kernel contains 8 and 16 bit access functions,
00062 but these violate the RapidIO specification.  The 8 and 16 bit
00063 functions are not supported on OCTEON.
00064 
00065 @subsubsection srio_maintenance_kernel_error 2.1.1 Error recovery
00066 
00067 - Reads: Maintenance read operations that fails will return a non zero
00068 error code.  Reads are synchronous such that the full operation has
00069 completed before the kernel's RapidIO function returns.
00070 
00071 - Writes: Maintenance write operations may fail either with a non zero
00072 error code, or log a kernel message.  Write operations are
00073 asynchronous such that the full operation will not have completed
00074 before the kernel's RapidIO function returns.  Errors that can be
00075 detected at submit will be returned as an error code.  Errors that
00076 occur after the operation is submitted to the SRIO block will generate
00077 kernel log messages since these are after the calling function has
00078 already returned.
00079 
00080 @subsection srio_maintenance_userspace 2.2. Linux userspace
00081 
00082 For applications running under userspace, the kernel exposes a 16MB
00083 window into the maintenance address space for every RapidIO device.
00084 Under "/sys/bus/rapidio/devices" the Linux kernel populates a
00085 directory tree representing the layout of the RapidIO system.  Under
00086 the directory for each device is a file "config".  Reads and writes to
00087 this file generate maintenance request to the device.  Reads and
00088 writes must be 4 byte aligned and be in multiples of 4 bytes.
00089 
00090 @note The current implementation of the RapidIO subsystem does not
00091 allow using the mmap() system call on this file.
00092 
00093 @subsubsection srio_maintenance_userspace_error 2.2.1 Error recovery
00094 
00095 - Reads: IO reads to the "config" file will return less bytes than
00096 requested when an error occurs.  The return value from the "read"
00097 system call will be the number of bytes successfully read through the
00098 maintenance operation.
00099 
00100 - Writes: Where possible, writes to the "config" file will return the
00101 number of bytes successfully written.  Errors that occur after the
00102 transaction is submitted to the SRIO block will generate kernel log
00103 messages since these are after the calling function has already
00104 returned.
00105 
00106 @subsection srio_maintenance_se 2.3. Simple executive
00107 
00108 The simple executive supports two methods of generating maintenance
00109 request.  These requests can be generated using either function calls
00110 or through physically mapped memory.  The functions involved are:
00111 
00112     - cvmx_srio_config_read32()
00113     - cvmx_srio_config_write32()
00114     - cvmx_srio_physical_map()
00115     - cvmx_srio_physical_unmap()
00116 
00117 The function cvmx_srio_physical_map() can be used to gain a physical
00118 address to the remote RapidIO device.  This physical address can then
00119 be passed to cvmx_phys_to_ptr() to generated a C pointer that directly
00120 generates maintenance requests.  Memory mapped requests have the same
00121 limitations as functions calls, so they must be 4 byte aligned and in
00122 multiples of 4 byte widths.
00123 
00124 @subsubsection srio_maintenance_se_error 2.3.1 Error recovery
00125 
00126 - Reads through function: Maintenance read operations that fails will
00127 return a non zero error code.  Reads are synchronous such that the
00128 full operation has completed before the function returns.
00129 
00130 - Reads through physical map: Reads using physically mapped memory
00131 will raise an asynchronous interrupt and return zero data.  It is up
00132 the application to handle the interrupt properly.  The default handler
00133 for the simple executive will print a message and continue.
00134 
00135 - Writes through function: Maintenance write operations may fail
00136 either with a non zero error code, or assert an error bit.  Write
00137 operations are asynchronous such that the full operation will not have
00138 completed before the function returns.  Errors that can be detected at
00139 submit will be returned as an error code.  Errors that occur after the
00140 operation is submitted to the SRIO block will generate error bits
00141 since these are after the calling function has already returned.
00142 
00143 - Writes through physical map: Maintenance operation that fail while using
00144     physically mapped memory will not report errors.
00145 
00146 @section srio_memory 3. Memory Operations (RapidIO format type 2, 5, and 6)
00147 
00148 RapidIO defines a rich set of memory based transactions supporting atomic
00149 access in addition to the more standard read/write model. Strict ordering of
00150 operations are not guaranteed unless proper synchronization barriers are
00151 implemented.
00152 
00153     - Types of Reads
00154         - NREAD - Normal reads
00155         - Atomic Test and swap
00156         - Atomic Swap
00157         - Atomic Compare and swap
00158     - Types of Writes
00159         - NWRITE - Normal writes
00160         - SWRITE - Streaming writes
00161         - NWRITE_R - Write with response
00162         - Atomic Set
00163         - Atomic Clear
00164         - Atomic Increment
00165         - Atomic Decrement
00166 
00167 RapidIO memory transactions are guaranteed operations.  Requests will
00168 be retried automatically by the hardware on failure.  In the event the
00169 hardware is unable to issue the request, the failure mode varies based
00170 on if the operation is a read or write.
00171 
00172 @subsection srio_memory_kernel 3.1. Linux kernel
00173 
00174 The official Linux RapidIO subsystem does not support memory mapped
00175 transactions. Cavium Inc. has extended the kernel's RapidIO subsystem
00176 by adding the following functions for memory access:
00177 
00178     - void *rio_map_memory(struct rio_dev *rdev, u64 offset, u64 length);
00179     - void rio_unmap_memory(struct rio_dev *rdev, u64 offset, u64 length, void *map);
00180 
00181 @note The Linux kernel does not supply an interface to any of the
00182 atomic operations.
00183 
00184 @subsubsection srio_memory_kernel_error 3.1.1 Error recovery
00185 
00186 - Reads: The kernel pointer returned as part of mapping the resource
00187 will return zero data on failure conditions.  An asynchronous error
00188 bit will assert and the kernel will display a message when an error
00189 occurs.  Information about the first failed access will be logged.
00190 
00191 - Writes: On failure, writes are dropped by the SRIO subsystem. If the
00192 write fails in the link between OCTEON and the SRIO device connected directly
00193 to it, OCTEON will display a message on failure. This message will occur once
00194 all the retires for the write transaction fail. Information about the first
00195 failed access will be logged.
00196 
00197 @subsection srio_memory_userspace 3.2. Linux userspace
00198 
00199 Cavium Inc. exposes the memory mapped functions available in the
00200 kernel through files under "/sys/bus/rapidio/devices".  Similar to the
00201 "config" file, the kernel creates a file "memory" for each available
00202 RapidIO device.  Each "memory" file represents the entire address
00203 space for a RapidIO device (2^34, 2^50, or 2^66 based on support
00204 addressing modes).  These files support read and write and may support
00205 mmap() in the future.
00206 
00207 @note Linux userspace does not supply an interface to any of the
00208 atomic operations.
00209 
00210 @subsubsection srio_memory_userspace_error 3.2.1 Error recovery
00211 
00212 - Reads: The read() system call will return the number of bytes
00213 successfully sent to the SRIO hardware.  Reads that fail will return
00214 zero data and the kernel will log a message.  No read status is
00215 returned to the userspace program.
00216 
00217 - Memory mapped reads: Reads that fail will return zero data and the
00218 kernel will log a message.  No read status is returned to the
00219 userspace program.
00220 
00221 - Writes: Writes to the "memory" file will return the number of
00222 bytes successfully written to the SRIO hardware.  Errors that occur
00223 after the transaction is submitted to the SRIO block will generate
00224 kernel log messages. No write status is returned to the userspace
00225 program.
00226 
00227 - Memory mapped writes: Memory mapped writes from userspace will not
00228 report failures.  The kernel may log an error, but userspace will not
00229 receive any signals or other error notification.  This is due to the
00230 asynchronous nature of writes.
00231 
00232 @subsection srio_memory_se 3.3. Simple executive
00233 
00234 The simple executive supplies two functions for working with physical
00235 address addressing remote RapidIO devices.  These functions are:
00236 
00237     - cvmx_srio_physical_map()
00238     - cvmx_srio_physical_unmap()
00239 
00240 Unlike maintenance operations, memory mapped transactions do not have
00241 any alignment or size constraints.
00242 
00243 @subsubsection srio_memory_se_error 3.3.1 Error recovery
00244 
00245 - Reads: The pointer returned as part of mapping the resource
00246 will return zero data on failure conditions.  An asynchronous error
00247 bit will assert and the executive will display a message when an error
00248 occurs.  Information about the first failed access will be logged.
00249 
00250 - Writes: Maintenance operation that fail while using physically
00251 mapped memory will not report failures.
00252 
00253 @subsection srio_memory_dma 3.4. DMA Operations
00254 
00255 In order for remote RapidIO devices to DMA in/out of OCTEON memory,
00256 the OCTEON BAR registers must be setup and the appropriate bus address
00257 must be given to the remote device.
00258 
00259 @b TBD
00260 
00261 @note There is no guarantee that RapidIO bus address for DMAs
00262 correspond to internal OCTEON physical addresses.  It is incorrect to
00263 pass an OCTEON physical address to a RapidIO device as a DMA
00264 source/destination.
00265 
00266 
00267 @section srio_doorbell 4. Doorbells (RapidIO format type 10)
00268 
00269 RapidIO allows devices to asynchronously send 16 bits of data to other
00270 devices using "doorbell" messages.  These messages are similar to MSI
00271 interrupts over PCIe.
00272 
00273 @subsection srio_doorbell_kernel 4.1. Linux kernel
00274 
00275 The existing Linux RapidIO API for doorbells has been implemented. Below is a
00276 list of functions related to doorbells in the kernel.
00277 
00278     - rio_send_doorbell()
00279     - rio_request_inb_dbell()
00280     - rio_release_inb_dbell()
00281     - rio_request_outb_dbell()
00282     - rio_release_outb_dbell()
00283 
00284 @note The Linux kernel API does not have the ability to report doorbell
00285 failures back to the caller.  The OCTEON SRIO implementation will log
00286 the failure, but the original requester will not know of a transmit
00287 doorbell failure.
00288 
00289 @subsection srio_doorbell_userspace 4.2. Linux userspace
00290 
00291 Doorbells are not exposed to userspace by the Linux RapidIO subsystem.
00292 
00293 @subsection srio_doorbell_se 4.3. Simple executive
00294 
00295 The following functions implement doorbells in the simple executive:
00296 
00297     - cvmx_srio_send_doorbell()
00298     - cvmx_srio_send_doorbell_status()
00299     - cvmx_srio_receive_doorbell()
00300 
00301 @section srio_port_writes 5. Port Writes (RapidIO format type 8)
00302 
00303 Maintenance port write transactions are used by the SRIO system to
00304 communicate asynchronous error status.  For example, switches are
00305 normally configured to issue port writes when a port link state
00306 changes.  OCTEON supports sending and receiving these messages through
00307 the SRIO soft packet FIFO.
00308 
00309 @subsection srio_port_writes_kernel 5.1. Linux kernel
00310 
00311 Incomming port writes are forwarded to the RapidIO subsytem through
00312 the function rio_inb_pwrite_handler().  Cavium's support for port
00313 writes in the kernel was backported from pending RapidIO patches.  The
00314 Linux kernel does not expose an interface for sending port writes.
00315 
00316 @subsection srio_port_writes_userspace 5.2. Linux userspace
00317 
00318 Port writes are not exposed to userspace by the Linux RapidIO subsystem.
00319 
00320 @subsection srio_port_writes_se 5.3. Simple executive
00321 
00322 Port writes can be sent from the simple executive using the same
00323 functions as used for memory access.  Port writes are a special type
00324 of transaction, supported using the CVMX_SRIO_WRITE_MODE_PORT
00325 enumeration.
00326 
00327     - cvmx_srio_physical_map()
00328     - cvmx_srio_physical_unmap()
00329 
00330 Ports writes are received from the SRIO soft FIFO.  These messages can
00331 be read using the following function.
00332 
00333     - cvmx_srio_receive_spf()
00334 
00335 
00336 @section srio_message 6. Packet Messages (RapidIO format type 11)
00337 
00338 A key benefit of RapidIO over PCIe is the ability to send arbitrary
00339 packetized data efficiently.  RapidIO can send packets of up to 4096
00340 bytes of data to another device with guaranteed delivery.  Hardware
00341 automatically retries failures on messages similarly to TCP.
00342 
00343 @subsection srio_message_kernel 6.1. Linux kernel
00344 
00345 Cavium Inc. does not support the kernel's existing RapidIO
00346 messaging API.  The API has a number of issues that cause performance
00347 problems as well as not exposing enough of RapidIO system features.
00348 For these reasons, Cavium Inc. supports RapidIO messaging through
00349 an ethernet device model.  This is documented in the following section
00350 describing the userspace API.
00351 
00352 @subsection srio_message_userspace 6.2. Linux userspace
00353 
00354 Linux has an ethernet device for each of the four standard RapidIO
00355 mailboxes.  With four mailboxes and two SRIO interfaces, the following
00356 ethernet interfaces are available through "ifconfig".
00357 
00358     - rio0 = Interface 0, send/receive on mailbox 0
00359     - rio1 = Interface 0, send/receive on mailbox 1
00360     - rio2 = Interface 0, send/receive on mailbox 2
00361     - rio3 = Interface 0, send/receive on mailbox 3
00362     - rio4 = Interface 1, send/receive on mailbox 0
00363     - rio5 = Interface 1, send/receive on mailbox 1
00364     - rio6 = Interface 1, send/receive on mailbox 2
00365     - rio7 = Interface 1, send/receive on mailbox 3
00366 
00367 Since the RapidIO transport is different from the expected ethernet
00368 transport, these devices treat MAC addresses specially.  Extra data
00369 describing the RapidIO message header fields is encoded into the
00370 destination MAC address.  The format of the MAC address is:
00371 
00372 <table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=1>
00373 <tr>
00374     <th>Byte</th>
00375     <th>Bits</th>
00376     <th>Description</th>
00377 </tr>
00378 <tr>
00379     <td>0-3</td>
00380     <td>31:0</td>
00381     <td>Must be zero</td>
00382 </tr>
00383 <tr>
00384     <td>4-5</td>
00385     <td>15:0</td>
00386     <td>16bits for the SRIO destination ID.</td>
00387 </tr>
00388 </table>
00389 
00390 RapidIO allows messages up to 4096 bytes, which is larger than what is
00391 allowed on the low level message transport.  It is necessary for the
00392 underlying hardware to break these messages into individual segments.
00393 The size of each segment is controlled by a define in the Cavium
00394 Networks ethernet driver.  Most systems will not need to adjust the
00395 default value, which is 256 bytes per segment (ssize=0xe).  This
00396 allows the maximum messages size using 16 segments with 256 bytes
00397 each, totalling 4096 bytes.
00398 
00399 @subsubsection srio_message_ioctl 6.2.1. Network Device IOCTLs
00400 
00401 Additional control of SRIO messages are exposed through "netdev"
00402 IOCTLs.  These IOCTLs are per network device and not application
00403 private.  The supported IOCTLs are defined in
00404 <b>linux/include/asm/octeon/octeon-ethernet-user.h</b>.
00405 The list below is only for reference as "octeon-ethernet-user.h" is
00406 the official specification.
00407 
00408 <table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=1>
00409 <tr>
00410     <th>IOCTL Command</th>
00411     <th>IOCTL Number</th>
00412     <th>Description</th>
00413 </tr>
00414 <tr>
00415     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_SETPRIO</td>
00416     <td>0x89F0</td>
00417     <td>Sets the SRIO priority for all messages sent on this interface. Priority 0-3. Default is 0</td>
00418 </tr>
00419 <tr>
00420     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_GETPRIO</td>
00421     <td>0x89F1</td>
00422     <td>Gets the SRIO priority for all messages sent on this interface. Priority 0-3</td>
00423 </tr>
00424 <tr>
00425     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_SETIDSIZE</td>
00426     <td>0x89F2</td>
00427     <td>Sets the device ID size used for all packets on this interface. 0 = 8 bit, 1 = 16 bit IDs. Default is 1</td>
00428 </tr>
00429 <tr>
00430     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_GETIDSIZE</td>
00431     <td>0x89F3</td>
00432     <td>Gets the device ID size used for all packets on this interface. 0 = 8 bit, 1 = 16 bit IDs</td>
00433 </tr>
00434 <tr>
00435     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_SETSRCID</td>
00436     <td>0x89F4</td>
00437     <td>Sets which source ID is used for all packets on this interface. 0 = primary ID, 1 = secondary ID. Default is 0</td>
00438 </tr>
00439 <tr>
00440     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_GETSRCID</td>
00441     <td>0x89F5</td>
00442     <td>Gets which source ID is used for all packets on this interface. 0 = primary ID, 1 = secondary ID</td>
00443 </tr>
00444 <tr>
00445     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_SETLETTER</td>
00446     <td>0x89F6</td>
00447     <td>Sets the letter code used for all packets on this interface. Letter code 0-3, or -1 for auto. Default is -1</td>
00448 </tr>
00449 <tr>
00450     <td>CAVIUM_NET_IOCTL_GETLETTER</td>
00451     <td>0x89F7</td>
00452     <td>Gets the letter code used for all packets on this interface. Letter code 0-3, or -1 for auto</td>
00453 </tr>
00454 </table>
00455 
00456 @note The OCTEON Linux embedded root filesystem contains a command line utility
00457 for accessing these IOCTLs. The utility, <b>rio-control</b>, is found in
00458 /usr/sbin and its source is located in embedded_rootfs/source/rio-control.c.
00459 
00460 @subsection srio_message_se 6.3. Simple executive
00461 
00462 The simple executive doesn't expose an API specifically for generating
00463 RapidIO messages.  Messages are handle by the normal OCTEON packet
00464 processing hardware, so they are treated similarly to ethernet
00465 packets.  When generating packets for transmit using
00466 cvmx_pko_send_packet_finish(), you must make sure the SRIO packet
00467 header is present at the beginning of the packet.  On reception using
00468 cvmx_pow_work_request_sync(), the SRIO receive packet header will
00469 always proceed the the packet data. Note the SRIO receive and transmit headers
00470 are different.
00471 
00472     - cvmx_pow_work_request_sync()
00473     - cvmx_pow_work_request_async()
00474     - cvmx_pko_send_packet_prepare()
00475     - cvmx_pko_send_packet_finish()
00476     - cvmx_pko_send_packet_finish3()
00477     - cvmx_srio_tx_message_header_t, the SRIO transmit header.
00478     - cvmx_srio_rx_message_header_t, the SRIO receive header.
00479 
00480 
00481 @section srio_enumeration 7. Discovery and Enumeration
00482 
00483 The OCTEON SDK relies on the Linux kernel to perform RapidIO device
00484 discovery and enumeration.  During initial boot the kernel's RapidIO
00485 subsystem will probe all OCTEON SRIO ports to discover what devices
00486 are available.  Any RapidIO devices discovered will create device
00487 structures in the kernel and entries under "/sys/bus/rapidio/devices".
00488 Discovered devices that haven't had device IDs assigned will be
00489 enumerated into the system per part 7 of the RapidIO specification.
00490 
00491 @note Devices with hard coded IDs, which violate the specification,
00492 will not be enumerated correctly.  These devices will not be
00493 discovered nor enumerated.
00494 
00495 @subsection srio_enumeration_switches 7.1 SRIO switch driver
00496 
00497 Pending RapidIO patches from the Linux kernel for SRIO switches have been
00498 backported into Cavium's Linux kernel. These changes add support for a
00499 number of SRIO switch vendors. These drivers can be found in
00500 "drivers/rapidio/switches".
00501 
00502 @subsection srio_enumeration_hotplug 7.2 Adding and removing devices
00503 
00504 @b TBD
00505 
00506 
00507 @section srio_types 8. RapidIO Low Level Packet Types

00586 
00587 @subsection srio_type_0 8.1 Type 0 Packet format (Implementation Defined)
00588 
00589 This packet type is unused.
00590 
00591 @subsection srio_type_1 8.2 Type 1 Packet format (Reserved)
00592 
00593 This packet type is reserved.
00594 
00595 @subsection srio_type_2 8.3 Type 2 Packet format (Request Class)
00596 <table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=1>
00597 <tr>
00598     <th>Layer</th>
00599     <th>Bits</th>
00600     <th>Name</th>
00601     <th>Description</th>
00602 </tr>
00603 <tr>
00604     <td rowspan=4>SRIO</td>
00605     <td>5</td>
00606     <td>ackID</td>
00607     <td>Acknowledge ID</td>
00608 </tr>
00609 <tr>
00610     <td>2</td>
00611     <td>reserved</td>
00612     <td>Reserved</td>
00613 </tr>
00614 <tr>
00615     <td>1</td>
00616     <td>CRF</td>
00617     <td>Critical Request Flow (Not supported)</td>
00618 </tr>
00619 <tr>
00620     <td>2</td>
00621     <td>prio</td>
00622     <td>Packet priority. 0 = lowest, 3 = highest</td>
00623 </tr>
00624 <tr>
00625     <td>Transport</td>
00626     <td>2</td>
00627     <td>tt</td>
00628     <td>
00629         - 0 8-bit deviceID fields
00630         - 1 16-bit deviceID fields
00631         - 2-3 Reserved</td>
00632 </tr>
00633 <tr>
00634     <td>Logical</td>
00635     <td>4</td>
00636     <td>ftype</td>
00637     <td>Format type = 0x2</td>
00638 </tr>
00639 <tr>
00640     <td rowspan=2>Transport</td>
00641     <td>8/16</td>
00642     <td>destinationID</td>
00643     <td>Destination ID</td>
00644 </tr>
00645 <tr>
00646     <td>8/16</td>
00647     <td>sourceID</td>
00648     <td>Source ID</td>
00649 </tr>
00650 <tr>
00651     <td rowspan=7>Logical</td>
00652     <td>4</td>
00653     <td>transaction</td>
00654     <td>
00655         - 0b0000-0011 Reserved
00656         - 0b0100      NREAD transaction
00657         - 0b0101-1011 Reserved
00658         - 0b1100      ATOMIC inc: post-increment the data
00659         - 0b1101      ATOMIC dec: post-decrement the data
00660         - 0b1110      ATOMIC set: set the data (write 0b11111...')
00661         - 0b1111      ATOMIC clr: clear the data (write 0b00000...')</td>
00662 </tr>
00663 <tr>
00664     <td>4</td>
00665     <td>rdsize</td>
00666     <td>Read Size</td>
00667 </tr>
00668 <tr>
00669     <td>8</td>
00670     <td>srcTID</td>
00671     <td>Source Tag ID to pair request and response</td>
00672 </tr>
00673 <tr>
00674     <td>0/16/32</td>
00675     <td>extended address</td>
00676     <td>Bits[47:32]/Bits[63:32]</td>
00677 </tr>
00678 <tr>
00679     <td>29</td>
00680     <td>address</td>
00681     <td>Bits[31:3], Address with last three bits missing</td>
00682 </tr>
00683 <tr>
00684     <td>1</td>
00685     <td>wdptr</td>
00686     <td>Word pointer. Used with rdsize/wrsize</td>
00687 </tr>
00688 <tr>
00689     <td>2</td>
00690     <td>xamsbs</td>
00691     <td>Bits[33:32]/Bits[49:48]/Bits[65:64]</td>
00692 </tr>
00693 <tr>
00694     <td>SRIO</td>
00695     <td>16</td>
00696     <td>CRC</td>
00697     <td>Cyclic Redundancy Code</td>
00698 </tr>

00953 </tr>

00958 </tr>
00959 <tr>
00960     <td>1</td>
00961     <td>CRF</td>
00962     <td>Critical Request Flow (Not supported)</td>
00963 </tr>
00964 <tr>
00965     <td>2</td>
00966     <td>prio</td>
00967     <td>Packet priority. 0 = lowest, 3 = highest</td>
00968 </tr>
00969 <tr>
00970     <td>Transport</td>
00971     <td>2</td>
00972     <td>tt</td>
00973     <td>
00974         - 0 8-bit deviceID fields
00975         - 1 16-bit deviceID fields
00976         - 2-3 Reserved</td>
00977 </tr>
00978 <tr>
00979     <td>Logical</td>
00980     <td>4</td>
00981     <td>ftype</td>
00982     <td>Format type = 0x8</td>
00983 </tr>
00984 <tr>

00994 </tr>
00995 <tr>
00996     <td rowspan=7>Logical</td>
00997     <td>4</td>
00998     <td>transaction</td>
00999     <td>
01000         - 0b0000      Specifies a maintenance read request
01001         - 0b0001      Specifies a maintenance write request
01002         - 0b0010      Specifies a maintenance read response
01003         - 0b0011      Specifies a maintenance write response
01004         - 0b0100      Specifies a maintenance port-write request
01005         - 0b0101-1111 Reserved</td>
01006 </tr>
01007 <tr>
01008     <td>4</td>

01016 </tr>

01019     <td>hopcount</td>
01020     <td>Number of hops to the device</td>
01021 </tr>
01022 <tr>
01023     <td>21</td>
01024     <td>config offset</td>
01025     <td>Double-word offset into the CAR/CSR register block for reads and writes</td>
01026 </tr>
01027 <tr>
01028     <td>1</td>
01029     <td>wdptr</td>
01030     <td>Word pointer. Used with rdsize/wrsize</td>
01031 </tr>
01032 <tr>
01033     <td>2</td>
01034     <td>reserved</td>
01035     <td>Reserved</td>
01036 </tr>
01037 <tr>
01038     <td>64*n</td>
01039     <td>data</td>
01040     <td>Read/Write data</td>
01041 </tr>
01042 <tr>
01043     <td>SRIO</td>
01044     <td>16</td>
01045     <td>CRC</td>
01046     <td>Cyclic Redundancy Code</td>
01047 </tr>

01233 @subsection srio_type_13 8.14 Type 13 Packet format (Response class)
01234 
01235 <table cellspacing=0 cellpadding=1>
01236 <tr>
01237     <th>Layer</th>
01238     <th>Bits</th>
01239     <th>Name</th>
01240     <th>Description</th>
01241 </tr>
01242 <tr>
01243     <td rowspan=4>SRIO</td>
01244     <td>5</td>
01245     <td>ackID</td>
01246     <td>Acknowledge ID</td>
01247 </tr>
01248 <tr>
01249     <td>2</td>
01250     <td>reserved</td>
01251     <td>Reserved</td>
01252 </tr>
01253 <tr>
01254     <td>1</td>
01255     <td>CRF</td>
01256     <td>Critical Request Flow (Not supported)</td>
01257 </tr>
01258 <tr>
01259     <td>2</td>
01260     <td>prio</td>
01261     <td>Packet priority. 0 = lowest, 3 = highest</td>
01262 </tr>
01263 <tr>
01264     <td>Transport</td>
01265     <td>2</td>
01266     <td>tt</td>
01267     <td>
01268         - 0 8-bit deviceID fields
01269         - 1 16-bit deviceID fields
01270         - 2-3 Reserved</td>
01271 </tr>
01272 <tr>
01273     <td>Logical</td>
01274     <td>4</td>
01275     <td>ftype</td>
01276     <td>Format type = 0xd</td>
01277 </tr>
01278 <tr>
01279     <td rowspan=2>Transport</td>
01280     <td>8/16</td>
01281     <td>destinationID</td>
01282     <td>Destination ID</td>
01283 </tr>
01284 <tr>
01285     <td>8/16</td>
01286     <td>sourceID</td>
01287     <td>Source ID</td>
01288 </tr>
01289 <tr>
01290     <td rowspan=4>Logical</td>
01291     <td>4</td>
01292     <td>transaction</td>
01293     <td>
01294         - 0b0000      RESPONSE transaction with no data payload
01295         - 0b0001      MESSAGE RESPONSE
01296         - 0b0002-0111 Reserved
01297         - 0b1000      RESPONSE transaction with data payload
01298         - 0b1001-1111 Reserved</td>
01299 </tr>
01300 <tr>
01301     <td>4</td>
01302     <td>status</td>
01303     <td>
01304         - 0b0000      DONE
01305         - 0b0001-0010 Reserved
01306         - 0b0011      RETRY
01307         - 0b0100-0110 Reserved
01308         - 0b0111      ERROR
01309         - 0b1000-1011 Reserved
01310         - 0b1100-1111 Implementation defined</td>
01311 </tr>
01312 <tr>
01313     <td>8</td>
